content: The Act is titled the "Protect and Preserve International Cultural Property Act" and defines "cultural property" according to the Hague Convention. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. SEC. 3. FINDINGS AND STATEMENT OF POLICY. Congress finds that protecting international cultural property is crucial for United States cultural diplomacy, demonstrating respect for other cultures and the shared heritage of humanity. This protection is necessary due to the loss, damage, and destruction of cultural property caused by various threats such as political instability, armed conflict, and natural disasters. Recent events in Egypt, including political instability, have resulted in the ransacking of museums and the destruction of ancient artifacts, leaving significant gaps in the historical record of the ancient Egyptian civilization. In Egypt and Iraq, political instability and armed conflict have led to the destruction and looting of museums, resulting in the loss of ancient artifacts. In Egypt, countless artifacts have been destroyed, leaving gaps in the historical record of the ancient Egyptian civilization. In Iraq, approximately 15,000 items, including amulets, sculptures, and cylinder seals, were looted from the Iraq Museum in Baghdad, with many items still unrecovered. In Syria, the civil war has led to the shelling of medieval cities, damage to UNESCO World Heritage Sites, and looting of museums and archaeological sites, dating back more than six millennia. In Syria, ongoing civil war has led to the shelling of medieval cities, damage to UNESCO World Heritage Sites, and looting of museums and archaeological sites. ISIS/ISIL has destroyed cultural sites and artifacts in Iraq and Syria. In Iraq and Syria, ISIS/ISIL has destroyed cultural sites and artifacts, looting and trafficking antiquities to fund their operations. In Mali, Ansar Dine destroyed tombs and shrines in Timbuktu, a center for trade, scholarship, and Islam. In Mali, the Al-Qaeda affiliated group Ansar Dine destroyed tombs and shrines in Timbuktu, threatening ancient manuscripts. In Afghanistan, the Taliban destroyed the Bamiyan Buddhas in 2001. In Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge systematically destroyed Buddhist temples, statues, and literature after seizing power in 1975. They also targeted mosques for destruction. During the Cultural Revolution in China, many antiques and parts of old Beijing were destroyed. Chinese authorities are now working to rebuild some of the lost architectural heritage. During the Cultural Revolution in China, many antiques and parts of old Beijing were destroyed. Chinese authorities are now working to rebuild some of the lost architectural heritage. In Haiti, the 2010 earthquake destroyed art, artifacts, and archives important to the people, and partially destroyed the 17th century Haitian city of Jacmel. The 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami affected eleven countries, causing massive loss of life and damaging or destroying libraries, archives, and UNESCO World Heritage sites. The 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami caused massive loss of life and damaged or destroyed cultural properties like libraries, archives, and UNESCO World Heritage Sites in eleven countries, including India and Sri Lanka. This destruction represents an irreparable loss of humanity's common cultural heritage. The 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami caused massive loss of life and damaged or destroyed cultural properties like libraries, archives, and UNESCO World Heritage Sites in eleven countries, including India and Sri Lanka. Heritage Sites such as Mahabalipuram in India, the Sun Temple of Koranak on the Bay of Bengal, and the Old Town of Galle and its Fortifications in Sri Lanka were affected. The destruction of these cultural properties represents an irreparable loss of humanity's common cultural heritage. The United States Armed Forces have played important roles in preserving and protecting cultural property, with President Franklin D. Roosevelt establishing the American Commission for the Protection and Salvage of Artistic and Historic Monuments in War Areas on June 23, 1943. The United States Armed Forces have played crucial roles in preserving cultural property. President Franklin D. Roosevelt established the American Commission for the Protection and Salvage of Artistic and Historic Monuments in War Areas on June 23, 1943, which formed Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives (MFAA) teams to protect cultural property during wartime. The Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives (MFAA) teams, also known as the "Monuments Men," were formed by the American Commission for the Protection and Salvage of Artistic and Historic Monuments in War Areas during World War II. They were credited with securing and returning art stolen by the Nazis. The U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield was established in 2006 to support the protection of cultural property. The U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield was founded in 2006 to support the implementation of the 1954 Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict and to coordinate with the United States military and other organizations in preserving international cultural property threatened by various disasters. The U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield was established in 2006 to support the implementation of the 1954 Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property during armed conflict and to collaborate with the U.S. military and other organizations in safeguarding international cultural property at risk from political instability, armed conflict, or natural disasters. The U.S. commits to protecting international cultural property at risk of destruction due to political instability, armed conflict, or disasters, in line with the 1954 Hague Convention and international law. This includes preventing the importation of pillaged, looted, or stolen cultural property. The United States pledges to protect cultural property during conflicts by preventing the importation of stolen items and enforcing existing laws to combat trafficking. SEC. 4. WHITE HOUSE COORDINATOR FOR INTERNATIONAL CULTURAL PROPERTY PROTECTION. The President appoints a White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection to coordinate efforts among federal agencies and submit annual reports to congressional committees. The White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection coordinates federal efforts, submits annual reports to Congress, provides policy recommendations, resolves interagency differences, and consults with domestic and international actors. The White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection coordinates federal efforts, submits annual reports to Congress, provides policy recommendations, resolves interagency differences, and consults with domestic and international actors to promote and protect cultural property. SEC. 5. INFORMATION ON ACTIVITIES TO PROTECT INTERNATIONAL CULTURAL PROPERTY. The Secretary of State must provide information to the White House Coordinator on efforts to protect international cultural property, including activities related to the Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in Armed Conflict. The Department has implemented procedures to safeguard international cultural property at risk due to conflicts or disasters, as required by the Hague Convention. Additionally, actions have been taken to protect cultural property in conflicts involving the United States. Actions have been taken to protect cultural property in conflicts involving the United States. The Administrator of USAID is required to submit information on activities to protect international cultural property to the White House. The Administrator of USAID is mandated to provide information to the White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection on efforts to safeguard international cultural property, including coordination with other entities. The USAID Coordinator provides information on efforts to protect international cultural property, including coordination with other agencies and organizations. The Department of Defense also submits information on its efforts in this area to the White House Coordinator. The Secretary of Defense submits information to the White House Coordinator on efforts to protect international cultural property, including activities related to the Hague Convention and other cultural protection statutes. The Department has implemented directives, policies, and regulations to protect international cultural property at risk of destruction. They have also taken actions to avoid damage to cultural property during construction activities abroad. The Department of Justice, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, submits information on efforts to protect international cultural property, including actions to prevent damage during construction activities abroad. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, submits information to the White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection on efforts to protect international cultural property, including statutes and regulations employed in criminal, civil, and civil forfeiture actions. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, provides information to the White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection on efforts to prevent trafficking in stolen and smuggled cultural property, including actions taken to ensure consistent and effective application of laws. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, provides information to the White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection on efforts to interdict trafficking in stolen and smuggled cultural property, including investigations into transnational organized crime. The Department has taken actions to ensure the consistent and effective application of law in cases related to international cultural property. Authorization for federal agencies to engage in international cultural property protection activities with the Smithsonian Institution. The Department of State, Defense, USAID, Homeland Security, Justice, Interior, National Archives, National Science Foundation, and other agencies can partner with the Smithsonian Institution to temporarily involve its personnel in international cultural property protection activities. Federal agencies can partner with the Smithsonian Institution to engage its personnel in international cultural property protection activities, with the agencies authorized to pay for salaries and expenses to support such efforts. The Secretary of State is authorized to make grants for international cultural property protection activities in at-risk areas. Additionally, emergency protection for Syrian cultural property is addressed. The President will apply import restrictions to archaeological and ethnological material of Syria as if Syria were a State Party to the Convention on the Cultural Property Implementation Act. These restrictions will take effect within 60 days of the enactment of this Act. Import restrictions will be applied to archaeological and ethnological material of Syria as if Syria were a State Party to the Convention on the Cultural Property Implementation Act. The restrictions will take effect within 60 days of the enactment of this Act, defining the material as cultural property unlawfully removed from Syria after August 18, 2011. The Act defines "archaeological or ethnological material of Syria" as cultural property unlawfully removed from Syria after August 18, 2011. The term "State Party" refers to countries under the Convention on the Cultural Property Implementation Act.
